Physicists tell us that the universe is expanding,
but does that mean we expand with it? I mean,

if so, wouldn't no one notice because everything
would scale up at the same relative size and
it would seem like nothing had changed?

Well, the truth is, the universe isn't expanding.
Space is. Of course, everything else in the

universe is "in" space, and ignoring the influence
of any other forces, when the space between

things expands, those things will appear to
be carried farther apart. But there are other

forces in the universe, and their strengths
aren't directly affected when space expands.

For example, gravity and electromagnetism
are able to hold atoms and solar systems together

because these forces are too strong for the
slow expansion of space to overcome.

Think of it like this - if you and your cat
are standing on a piece of ground that starts

to stretch horizontally between you, the ground
will pull you and your cat away from each

other. But if the leash is strong enough - in
particular, if it's stronger than the friction

force between your feet and the ground - it'll
hold you and your cat together as space expands
beneath you.

In the real universe, it's the strength of
the electromagnetic force that determines

the effective sizes of particles, atoms, and
molecules so that even if the space they're

in expands, the molecules don't. Electromagnetism
is basically the leash that holds atoms and

molecules together - and gravity is the leash
that holds solar systems and galaxies together.

Only over super super long distances is gravity's
attraction weak enough and the cumulative

expansion of all that space big enough to
cause galaxies and galactic clusters to actually

grow more distant from one another over time
- we know this because the light from distant

galaxies gets red-shifted as it's stretched
by the expansion of the space it's traveling

through. Gravity certainly still pulls distant
objects towards each other, but space expands
faster. Basically, the cat is
off
the leash.

The redshift of light is easily differentiated from the intrinsic color of 
the light by the techniques of spectroscopy. The spectrum of light from a 
star or galaxy generally contains sharply defined black bands, called 
absorption bands, which represent energy absorbed at known 
energies/wavelengths by the gasses in the source. The shift of the 
absorption bands in the redshifted light compared with the same bands 
observed in the same gasses on earth establishes the redshift. (Emission 
bands are sometimes used in the same way.) The Wikipedia article titled 
"Redshift" has a very clear picture of redshifted absorption bands.

comments.text:
+DJ Qaz You might  be interested in some numbers.
The expansion rate of the universe is called the Hubble Parameter (or 
Hubble Constant). The Hubble Parameter is now measured at about 70 
kilometers per second per Megaparsec. So that means that the expansion of 
the universe causes galaxies to recede at a velocity which increases by 70 
km/sec for each Megaparsec of distance from the earth. (A Megaparsec is 
3.26 Million Light Years.) This sounds like a lot of speed, but it's 
actually fairly slow compared with the speed of stars and planets in their 
orbits. So this speed is negligible at distances of stars and planets, and 
is easily compensated for by the force of gravity. But at a big distance 
between galaxies like 100 Megaparsecs, the recession speed due to the 
expansion of the universe is  7,000 km/sec.

The scale of the universe when light is emitted from a galaxy is indicated 
by the redshift of the light observed. Redshift is a dimensionless number 
usually designated by the letter "Z."  It's easily derived that Z is 
related to the scale of the universe "a" by:

1 + Z = a(now) / a(then) .

So for a redshift  Z = 5,    a(then) = 1/6 of the scale of the universe 
now.  Expressed another way, the light is from a galaxy that is six times 
farther away from earth now than it was when the light was emitted......due 
to the expansion of the universe.

+DJ Qaz The scale of everything DOES change, but it's only observed over 
the vast distances between galaxies. It's a metric expansion (see the 
Wikipedia article on "Metric Expansion of Space") which is so small at 
relatively short distances (less than many tens of millions of light 
years), that it's negligible. It's so small at the scale of planets, stars, 
and the diameter of galaxies, that these things are never observed to 
change in scale. But at the VAST distances BETWEEN galaxies, the 
expansion rate becomes enormous, relative to an observer on earth. At a 
distance of about 14 billion light years, galaxies are receding from earth 
at the speed of light. Beyond that, they recede even faster. So the effect 
is that the size of the galaxies never change due to the expansion of the 
universe, but the distance BETWEEN them, and the speed with which they're 
moving away from the earth become enormous at great distances.

The expansion is detected and measured by the redshift of the light from 
distant galaxies that is physically stretched to longer wavelengths (which 
makes it redder) as it travels through expanding space at great distances. 
As for the scale of the expansion, the light from a galaxy with a measured 
redshift of 8, left it when the galaxy was only about 3 billion light years 
from earth, and now as the light arrives at earth, the object is about 30 
billion light years distant. This is an enormous factor of ten increase in 
the distance due to cosmological expansion. But the size of the galaxy, if 
it still exists, has not undergone any increase in scale.
